[amargo] Tenía razón. Cuatro años, y yo tenía—tenía toda la puta razón. [pausa] Los documentos falsificados, las cuentas en paraísos fiscales, todo. [frustrado] Cada cosa que dije que pasaría, pasó exactamente como predije. [suspiro] ¿Y sabes qué? No sirve de nada. [muy triste] Nada de eso importa porque el juez igualmente falló en contra nuestra.

[enfadado] ¡Los teníamos! Teníamos pruebas del fraude ahí mismo delante y el juez simplemente... [voz que se apaga] No sé, a lo mejor le untaron o algo. [susurrando fuerte] 23 millones de euros, a tomar por culo. [arrepentido] Y Sarah, ella confió en mí cuando le dije que podíamos ganar esto.

[molesto] No paro de darle vueltas, ¿sabes? La forma en que su cara se... se descompuso cuando leyeron el veredicto. [pausa] Perdió su empresa, su casa, básicamente todos los ahorros de su vida luchando contra esto y yo—yo le dije que siguiera adelante. [llorando mientras habla] Porque sabía que tenía razón. [amargo] ¡Y la tenía! Eso es lo peor, tenía razón en cada puto detalle.

[exhausto] Pero tener razón no, eh... no va a pagar la universidad de sus hijos ahora. [muy bajito] No le devuelve cuatro años de su vida. [suspiro] Joder, ¿de qué sirve tener buen ojo si el sistema está completamente podrido de todas formas?

[bitter] I was right. Four years, and I was—I was completely right about everything. [pause] The forged documents, the offshore accounts, all of it. [frustrated] Every single thing I said would happen, happened exactly like I predicted. [sigh] And you know what? It doesn't matter. [very sad] None of it matters because the judge still ruled against us.

[angry] We had them! We literally had proof of the fraud sitting right there and the judge just... [trailing off] I don't know, maybe he was paid off or something. [whispering loudly] Twenty-three million dollars, gone. [regretful] And Sarah, she trusted me when I said we could win this. 

[upset] I keep replaying it in my head, you know? The way her face just... collapsed when they read the verdict. [pause] She lost her company, her house, basically her entire life savings fighting this and I—I told her to keep going. [crying while speaking] Because I knew I was right. [bitter] And I was! That's the worst part, I was absolutely right about every single detail. 

[exhausted] But being right doesn't, um... it doesn't put her kids through college now. [very quietly] It doesn't bring back four years of her life. [sigh] God, what's even the point of having good instincts if the system's just completely broken anyway?

subject: Finally proving your lawyer instincts were right about the case, but your client still loses everything
